awd_titl_txt: RUI: Nitrogenase and friends: Uncovering how diazotrophs regulate and maintain nitrogenase activity under unfavorable environmental conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrogenase is an enzyme found in certain bacteria, called diazotrophs, that converts nitrogen gas into ammonia, an essential nutrient for plant growth and, thus, nitrogenase is critical to agriculture. With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Cedric Owens of Chapman University to determine how diazotrophs maintain nitrogenase activity under environmental conditions that would typically be expected to inactivate the enzyme. Nitrogenase is inhibited by both carbon monoxide, a metabolic product, and oxygen, an essential gas for aerobic respiration in many diazotrophs. This project studies the countermeasures diazotrophs have taken to protect nitrogenase from inactivation by carbon monoxide, and how nitrogenase activity is regulated by cellular levels of oxygen and oxidizing compounds. Results from this project will enhance the understanding of nitrogenase activity in diazotrophs and potentially inform the design of synthetic nitrogen fixation systems that are more resistant to environmental inactivation. This project broadens participation of undergraduate students in research at Chapman University (a 4-year college) and at Santa Ana College (a 2-year minority serving college). Furthermore, a faculty member from Santa Ana College participates in research activities through a summer workshop and, together with the Dr. Owens, develops biochemistry experiments to teach fundamental chemical concepts to first-year general chemistry students. 

The two nitrogen fixing proteins being studied in this project are CowN, which responds to carbon monoxide (CO), and alpha-proteobacterial NifA, which responds to cellular oxygen and/or oxidation-reduction (redox) levels. While CO is a potent inhibitor of molybdenum containing nitrogenase (Mo-nitrogenase, the most common nitrogenase), it is a substrate that is reduced to short-chain hydrocarbons by the alternative vanadium-containing nitrogenase (V-nitrogenase). The mechanistic reason for the differing effects is unknown and is not explained by the enzymes' dissimilar metal compositions. Interestingly, Mo-nitrogenase tolerates CO in the presence of a small protein, CowN, which is expressed in a CO-dependent manner. The first aim of this project is to apply enzymological, biophysical and structural approaches to uncover the mechanism by which CowN protects Mo-nitrogenase from CO inhibition and determine if CowN alters Mo-nitrogenase reactivity. NifA is the main transcriptional regulator of nitrogenase, sensing either redox levels, oxygen levels, or both. The second aim is to use structural biology, spectroscopic and biophysical tools, in order to test the hypothesis that redox and/or oxygen levels are sensed through a previously uncharacterized iron-sulfur cluster via a non-canonical environmental sensing mechanism. The results of the project are expected to yield critical information on the cellular conditions required for nitrogenase expression.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ammonia is an important plant nutrient and a component in fertilizer. Ammonia is generated industrially through the Haber-Bosch process and naturally through biological nitrogen fixation. The Haber-Bosch reaction is a critical industrial process since it helps supply modern agriculture with ammonia, however, it utilizes vast amounts of energy since the reaction takes place under high heat and pressure. Furthermore, excess ammonia fertilization causes waterway pollution. Biological nitrogen fixation, in contrast, is both non-polluting since it does not produce runoff, and it takes place under ambient temperature and pressure.

Biological nitrogen fixation is catalyzed by the enzyme nitrogenase, which can be found in specialized bacteria called diazotrophs. Studying nitrogenase is scientifically important since it may lead to the development of new catalysts to improve industrial ammonia production. Moreover, greater understanding of how nitrogenase operates may allow us to engineer bacteria to become more effective at ammonia production, in turn lowering the need for industrially produced ammonia. In the long term such developments would be beneficial to farmers who would save money on fertilizer and be good for the environment thanks to decreased waterway pollution.

The specific goals of this project were (1) to determine how nitrogenase is protected from inhibition by the gas carbon monoxide, a gas that is both produced naturally through soil chemical processes and through combustion and (2) to determine how nitrogenase expression is regulated by redox levels.

(1) Carbon monoxide binds tightly to nitrogenase and prevents it from making ammonia. However, diazotrophs were known to have a protective mechanism that allow nitrogenase to evade carbon monoxide inhibition. The details of this mechanism were unknown at the outset of this project. Our work characterized a protein called CowN, determining that CowN binds to nitrogenase and prevents carbon monoxide from binding and inhibiting nitrogenase. Thanks to CowN, nitrogenase is able to function even if carbon monoxide is present. Furthermore, we biochemically characterized CowN and determined which parts of the protein are important for its function. This new information is interesting from a fundamental science point of view since it provides new insights into how gases (like carbon monoxide) access nitrogenase’s active site. More importantly, this work revealed a key mechanism that allows diazotrophs to tolerate the inhibitor carbon monoxide.

(2) Diazotrophs only express nitrogenase when cellular conditions are reducing, meaning that there is enough redox energy present and oxygen concentrations are low. The protein that regulates nitrogenase expression is called NifA. It is a large protein whose mechanism of redox sensing is poorly characterized. Our work focused on NifA’s DNA binding domain. We hypothesized that a pair of amino acids in the domain were responsible for redox sensing. However, biochemical analysis of the DNA binding domain revealed that the amino acid pair was not responsible for redox sensing. Although this work did not support our hypothesis, it shed light on NifA function and, more importantly, on the DNA-binding domain function of NifA and related proteins.

In summary, the scientific outcomes of our work led to a greater understanding of CowN-mediated protection of nitrogenase from carbon monoxide and NifA function. In the long term, this work may aid biochemical engineering efforts to enhance nitrogenase activity by improving carbon monoxide tolerance or altering nitrogenase expression by NifA.

The broader impact of this work lies primarily in training opportunities afforded to undergraduate students. Students who worked on this project came from both Chapman University as well as local community college districts (primarily the Rancho Santiago Community College district in Orange County, CA). In total, 36 students from Chapman University worked on this project. In addition, eleven community college students participated in this research over the summer. Students benefited from the experience by gaining practical scientific research and communication skills. Student publications and presentations are evidence for their scientific success. In total, 21 undergraduate students appeared as co-authors on papers resulting from this project and students gave 20 external presentations at refereed conferences. Furthermore, research participation on this project aided their academic careers since 100% of Chapman students who worked on this project graduated (compared to the 80% university average) and 10/11 community college students transferred to a four-year school within one year of working on this project (compared to the approx. 9% transfer rate for the Rancho Santiago Community College district). Finally, one Chapman student and four community college students were employed part or full for six to twelve months after their summer research experience ended, allowing them to produce scientific results while gaining further research training and supporting their own education.
